page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Auxiliaries
page.introduction: Some languages have auxiliary elements that are separate words, and some can have more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples are given for English transitive single-clause sentences.

EnglishExample.exItem: The boy will hit the ball.
The boy might have hit the ball.
The boy might have been hitting the ball.

form.prompt: Think of any similar examples from your language and key them here:

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have any auxiliary elements that are separate words?
Is an auxiliary element required in every sentence?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, at least one is always required

radioGroup.prompt: Can there be more than one auxiliary in a single sentence?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, more than one may occur before the verb phrase

prompt.span: After an auxiliary, is the normal VSO word order maintained?
Before an auxiliary, is the normal OSV word order maintained?

radioGroup.radio: Yes, the order is always Aux V S then other elements other elements then S V Aux
No, the subject may come directly after the Aux and before the verb verb and before the Aux

form.instruction:
The auxiliary elements need to have the category Aux. If a particular form can also stand alone as the main verb in the sentence, you need to have two separate entries, one with the category Aux and one with the category V. Choose one of the following options, depending on your situation:
If you already have auxiliaries marked with the category Aux in your lexicon nothing more needs to be done.
If you have auxiliaries marked in your lexicon with a distinct category all their own, but it is different from Aux, go to the Category Mapper and map your morphological category to Aux.
If auxiliaries are mixed in with another category in the lexicon, you need to add the feature Aux to each appropriate entry so the category will be changed.
